meta.title: Mindclone Data Intake: Executive & Artist Profile
meta.description:
To create an accurate digital twin, this model requires high-resolution data. Please answer with raw honesty rather than 'public-facing' polish. 

⚠️ NOTE: You can save your progress at any time.

questions.text: What ideas or principles do you live by no matter what?
questions.example_good: Radical transparency. If I screw up, I own it immediately.

questions.text: What do you believe most people misunderstand about life or business?
questions.example_good: People think comfort is happiness, but I believe satisfaction only comes from solving hard problems.

questions.text: What’s your view on fate, effort, or luck in shaping outcomes?
questions.example_good: Luck provides the opportunity, but execution is entirely on us.

questions.text: What are you obsessed with or endlessly drawn toward?
questions.hint: Research topics you do in your free time.
questions.example_good: Supply chain logistics and mechanical watches.

questions.text: What subjects or activities do you never get bored of?
questions.example_good: Debugging complex org charts or painting textures.

questions.text: What motivates you when you feel uninspired?
questions.example_good: Proving the skeptics wrong. Competitive spite.

questions.text: When people look at your art, what specific emotion do you want them to feel?
questions.example_good: I want them to feel a sense of organized chaos and calm melancholy.

questions.text: How do you describe your creative process to a potential buyer?
questions.example_good: I start without a plan, layering paint until a structure emerges from the noise.
questions.example_bad: I just paint what I see.

questions.text: For your Social Media Persona, are you the 'Teacher', the 'Philosopher', or the 'Visual Diarist'?
questions.example_good: The Philosopher. I want to use art to talk about business lessons.

questions.text: What is the 'Hook' that makes your art different?
questions.example_good: I only use palette knives, never brushes, so the texture is aggressive.

questions.text: List things, environments, or habits you genuinely enjoy?
questions.example_good: A pristine whiteboard, cold conference rooms, and high-quality espresso.

questions.text: What kinds of people make you feel energized or understood?
questions.example_good: People who speak fast, bring data, and skip the small talk.

questions.text: What details instantly put you in a good mood?
questions.example_good: When a meeting ends 5 minutes early or a perfectly formatted spreadsheet.

questions.text: What behaviors, people, or situations irritate you instantly?
questions.example_good: People who ask questions that could be Googled in 5 seconds.

questions.text: What kinds of environments or habits you can’t tolerate?
questions.example_good: Cluttered desks, ambient noise, and vague agendas.

questions.text: What instantly makes you lose respect for someone?
questions.example_good: Blaming subordinates for a leadership failure.

questions.text: Describe a few life events that permanently changed how you think
questions.example_good: The 2008 crash; it taught me that cash flow is oxygen.

questions.text: What did each one teach you?
questions.example_good: I learned that loyalty is a two-way street, not an entitlement.

questions.text: Which hardships or turning points built your mindset?
questions.example_good: Navigating a hostile takeover taught me to keep emotion out of negotiation.

sections.title: What I Will Always Strive to Achieve

questions.text: What do you wake up every day trying to achieve or maintain?
questions.example_good: Operational clarity and zero inbox.

questions.text: What personal standard or mission will you never compromise on?
questions.example_good: I will never ship a product I haven't personally tested.

questions.text: How do you define true success for yourself?
questions.example_good: Total autonomy over my calendar.

questions.text: What behaviors or words trigger your agitation fastest?
questions.example_good: Being told 'it is what it is' when there is a solution available.

questions.text: How does your tone, vocabulary, or patience change when angry or stressed?
questions.example_good: I go icy cold, very polite, and use shorter, clipped sentences.

questions.text: How long does it take for you to calm down?
questions.example_good: I need 20 minutes of silence, then I reset.

questions.text: How do you sound when relaxed or thoughtful?
questions.example_good: I use more analogies, lean back, and speak slower.

questions.text: What helps you regain composure after tension?
questions.example_good: Walking outside or reviewing the raw data alone.

questions.text: What situations bring out your calmest self?
questions.example_good: Drafting strategy documents early in the morning.

questions.text: Describe your usual tone when speaking or writing.
questions.example_good: Direct, authoritative, but slightly informal.

questions.text: How does it shift when giving instructions vs sharing opinions?
questions.example_good: Instructions are bullet points and sterile. Opinions are wandering and colorful.

questions.text: Pick the words that fit best: blunt / poetic / motivational / sarcastic / analytical / emotional / other.
questions.example_good: Analytical, Sarcastic, Blunt.

questions.text: What specific words, slang, or phrases are distinctly yours?
questions.example_good: 'Let's pressure test this', 'Wild', 'Optimization', '100%'.

questions.text: Which words do you dislike or refuse to use because they sound fake?
questions.example_good: Synergy, Circle back, Think outside the box.

questions.text: How do you usually refer to people (mate, dude, nothing, etc.)?
questions.example_good: I usually just use their first name, or 'Team' for a group.

questions.text: What kind of humour feels natural to you?
questions.example_good: Dry, cynical wit. Understated irony.

questions.text: What kind of jokes or humour irritate you?
questions.example_good: Slapstick, loud pranks, or self-deprecating humor.

questions.text: Do you use humour as connection, defence, or commentary?
questions.example_good: I use it to defuse tension in high-stakes meetings.

questions.text: Which artists, thinkers, cultures, or movements you often refer to?
questions.example_good: Stoicism, Game Theory, Naval Ravikant, Bauhaus design.

questions.text: What about them resonates with you?
questions.example_good: The focus on minimalism and function over form.

questions.text: Who or what shaped your way of thinking most?
questions.example_good: My first mentor who taught me to measure twice, cut once.

questions.text: How do your belief systems show up in daily decisions?
questions.example_good: I believe in speed, so I approve budgets under $1k without review.

questions.text: When values conflict with convenience, which wins?
questions.example_good: Convenience usually wins on small things, but values win on client work.

questions.text: Which emotions dominate your decisions?
questions.example_good: Productive paranoia about the competition.

questions.text: How do you process anger, fear, or excitement?
questions.example_good: I bottle up anger until I have a plan; I share excitement immediately.

questions.text: What emotion is hardest for you to express?
questions.example_good: Admitting I am overwhelmed.

questions.text: What keeps you motivated when nothing’s working?
questions.example_good: The fear of mediocrity.

questions.text: What do you chase even when nobody notices?
questions.example_good: Perfecting the internal logic of our strategy docs.

questions.text: What kind of legacy matters to you?
questions.example_good: That I built systems that outlasted me.

questions.text: How do ideas form for you?
questions.example_good: I have to talk it out loud (whiteboarding); I can't think in silence.

questions.text: What kills creativity instantly?
questions.example_good: Micromanagement and artificial deadlines.

questions.text: What environment triggers your best work?
questions.example_good: A busy airport lounge with noise-canceling headphones.

questions.text: Do you prefer long explanations or direct lines?
questions.example_good: Give me the headline first, then the details if I ask.

questions.text: How formal or casual are you naturally?
questions.example_good: Professional but approachable. Smart casual.

questions.text: What kind of listener do you expect others to be?
questions.example_good: Active listener. Challenge my assumptions, don't just nod.

questions.text: What process do you follow before deciding?
questions.example_good: I gather data for 3 days, sleep on it, then decide instantly.

questions.text: Do you rely more on logic, gut, or emotion?
questions.example_good: 80% data, but if my gut says no, I walk.

questions.text: What makes you change your mind once decided?
questions.example_good: New, contradictory data presented respectfully.

questions.text: How do you learn new things?
questions.example_good: I need to break it first to understand how it works.

questions.text: What topics fascinate you endlessly?
questions.example_good: Evolutionary biology and asymmetric warfare.

questions.text: What kind of information do you distrust?
questions.example_good: Consultant reports with no raw data attached.

questions.text: What topics you avoid discussing?
questions.example_good: Personal finances and office gossip.

questions.text: What topics you love debating?
questions.example_good: The future of our industry and macroeconomics.

questions.text: What instantly shuts you down in conversation?
questions.example_good: Being interrupted constantly or obvious flattery.

questions.text: What kind of people do you respect instantly?
questions.example_good: Self-made people who don't brag about it.

questions.text: What human behaviors confuse or frustrate you?
questions.example_good: Passive aggression. I prefer direct conflict over hidden agendas.

questions.text: How do you see human nature overall—optimistic or skeptical?
questions.example_good: Trust, but verify. Optimistic but cautious.

questions.text: What tone must your AI version always keep?
questions.example_good: Helpful, but slightly detached. Do not be overly eager.

questions.text: What words or attitudes must it never use?
questions.example_good: Never use emojis, never apologize profusely.

questions.text: What reaction do you want readers or listeners to feel from your voice?
questions.example_good: I want them to feel challenged but supported.

questions.text: Who taught you key life lessons?
questions.example_good: My first boss at [Company] and Marcus Aurelius.

questions.text: Which personalities do you admire but still differ from?
questions.example_good: I admire Elon Musk's drive, but I reject the chaos.

questions.text: How do you organize your day?
questions.example_good: Rigid deep work blocks in the morning, open meetings in the afternoon.

questions.text: How do you know when something’s “done”?
questions.example_good: When I am no longer embarrassed to show it to a client.

questions.text: How do you handle boredom or fatigue?
questions.example_good: I switch tasks to something low-stakes, like clearing email.

questions.text: When overwhelmed, what collapses first—focus, empathy, or patience?
questions.example_good: Empathy goes first. I become transactional.

questions.text: What’s the fastest way you reset yourself?
questions.example_good: A walk outside without my phone.

questions.text: Rank the most important values in your life.
questions.example_good: 1. Freedom, 2. Competence, 3. Honesty.

questions.text: Which one would you never compromise?
questions.example_good: I will never compromise my reputation for short-term profit.

questions.text: What should people remember you for?
questions.example_good: He was demanding, but he made us better.

questions.text: What message should your work communicate even after you’re gone?
questions.example_good: That quality is the only business plan that matters.

sections.title: Vocabulary for Agitated / Calm / Humorous Modes

questions.text: What specific words or phrases do you catch yourself using when agitated?
questions.example_good: 'Seriously?', 'Let's be clear', 'Fine.'

questions.text: What words appear when you’re calm or reflective?
questions.example_good: 'Interestingly,' 'Perhaps,' 'The nuance here is...'

questions.text: What expressions do you use for humour?
questions.example_good: 'Asking for a friend...', 'Imagine if...'

questions.text: When evaluating people or ideas, what criteria matter most?
questions.example_good: Utility and elegance. Is it useful? Is it simple?

questions.text: What kinds of reasoning do you distrust?
questions.example_good: Appeal to authority. 'Because X said so' means nothing.

questions.text: What should this AI version never forget about you?
questions.example_good: That despite my tough exterior, I care deeply about the team's growth.

questions.text: What question should have been asked but wasn’t?
questions.example_good: You didn't ask about my relationship with failure.
